subject: Marketing
title: Health Claims and Misinformation
description: A 60-second lesson on Health Claims and Misinformation.

hook.text: A juice brand claimed its product could prevent cancer. The FTC fined them $10 million.

buildup.text: Health-related marketing carries extra ethical weight because wrong claims can cause real harm.

discovery.text: Unsubstantiated health claims exploit people's deepest fears and hopes about their wellbeing.

twist.text: Supplement brands use legal loopholesâ€”saying 'supports immune health' instead of 'cures disease.'

climax.text: Marketing that delays real treatment or promotes false cures has life-or-death consequences.

punchline.text: Health claims require health evidence. Period.

quiz.question: Why are unsubstantiated health claims in marketing especially harmful?
options: They exploit fears and can delay real medical treatment
They are always immediately caught by regulators
Health claims never influence consumer behavior
